text.headline: Educational Equity Watch
text.text: New York State School Districts labelled Predominantly BIPOC, Predominantly White, and Integrated

media.caption: View from Hook Mountain in Hook Mountain State Park, overlooking the Hudson River, in November 2015

text.headline: EAST RAMAPO CENTRAL SCHOOL DISTRICT (SPRING VALLEY)
text.text: The East Ramapo Central School District (Spring Valley) in Rockland county had 611 students enrolled in the 2017 cohort. It can be classified as a predominately BIPOC school district (96.2% BIPOC, 3.8% white). The district is in the 'Urban-Suburban High Needs' Needs to Resource Category (75.9% of the students in the 2017 cohort were identified as economically disadvantaged). Additional characteristics: 28.5% English Language Learners, 18.7% students with disabilities, and 9.2% homeless. The graduation rate within 5 years for the 2017 cohort was 80% with 23% of students receiving an advanced regents. The dropout percentage was 13%.

media.caption: Geneseo Normal School Front View Geneseo (NY) 1904

text.headline: GENESEO CENTRAL SCHOOL DISTRICT
text.text: The Geneseo Central School District in Livingston county had 57 students enrolled in the 2017 cohort. It can be classified as a predominately white school district (12.3% BIPOC, 87.7% white). The district is in the 'Average Needs' Needs to Resource Category (31.6% of the students in the 2017 cohort were identified as economically disadvantaged). Additional characteristics: 1.8% English Language Learners, 14% students with disabilities, and 1.8% homeless. The graduation rate within 5 years for the 2017 cohort was 89% with 63% of students receiving an advanced regents. The dropout percentage was 7%.

media.caption: Soldier's Monument, Batavia, N. Y., by Tichnor Brothers, c. 1930-1945, from the Digital Commonwealth
media.credit: Tichnor Brothers, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.headline: BATAVIA CITY SCHOOL DISTRICT
text.text: The Batavia City School District in Genesee county had 163 students enrolled in the 2017 cohort. It can be classified as an integrated school district (29.4% BIPOC, 70.6% white). The district is in the 'Rural High Needs' Needs to Resource Category (43.6% of the students in the 2017 cohort were identified as economically disadvantaged). Additional characteristics: 1.2% English Language Learners, 16% students with disabilities, and 1.2% homeless. The graduation rate within 5 years for the 2017 cohort was 96% with 45% of students receiving an advanced regents. The dropout percentage was 2%.
